summary.value:
Original Citation: Shnabel, Nurit, and Arie Nadler. "A needs-based model of reconciliation: satisfying the differential emotional needs of victim and perpetrator as a key to promoting reconciliation." Journal of personality and social psychology 94.1 (2008): 116.

Target of replication: The current study seeks to replicate the findings that participants in the perpetrator condition would indicate a need for social acceptance and be more likely to reconcile after their sense of moral acceptance was restored, whereas participant in the victim condition would indicate a need for power and would be more likely to reconcile after their sense of power was restored. It specifically focuses on the interaction between message and role in the after condition. More detail can be found in the replication report.

registration_responses.summary:
Original Citation: Shnabel, Nurit, and Arie Nadler. "A needs-based model of reconciliation: satisfying the differential emotional needs of victim and perpetrator as a key to promoting reconciliation." Journal of personality and social psychology 94.1 (2008): 116.

Target of replication: The current study seeks to replicate the findings that participants in the perpetrator condition would indicate a need for social acceptance and be more likely to reconcile after their sense of moral acceptance was restored, whereas participant in the victim condition would indicate a need for power and would be more likely to reconcile after their sense of power was restored. It specifically focuses on the interaction between message and role in the after condition. More detail can be found in the replication report.

attributes.title: SNAP Judgments: Reactions to SNAP Participants’ Grocery Choices

q1.value: SNAP Judgments: Reactions to SNAP Participants’ Grocery Choices

q3.value: This research aims to understand predictors of negative judgments toward SNAP recipients and the role of those judgments on downstream SNAP policy support. Do people’s attitudes toward SNAP recipients and SNAP policy depend on the groceries shoppers purchase using SNAP benefits? Do characteristics, such as race, of the observed SNAP shoppers impact people’s attitudes toward SNAP? Are SNAP shoppers negatively judged because of their food choices or because they are poor and using federal assistance? This research examines judgments of SNAP shoppers and SNAP policy using hypothetical situations wherein participants observe SNAP shoppers at a grocery store check-out. We will conduct a 2 (grocery choice: healthful, unhealthful) x 2 (shopper: SNAP recipient; poor, non-recipient) x 2 (race: white, black) between-subjects design to determine if shopper grocery choices and characteristics affect immorality judgments and SNAP policy support.

q4.value:
H1: Participants will morally judge SNAP recipients and non-recipients the same for buying unhealthful groceries (no penalty for SNAP receipt).
H2: Participants will judge SNAP recipients as more moral than non-recipients for buying healthful groceries (premium for SNAP receipt).
H3: Participants will be more supportive of SNAP in the healthful condition than in the unhealthful condition, across both shopper types.
H4: Race (white, black) will moderate the effect of grocery choice (healthful, unhealthful), but not shopper type (SNAP recipient, non-recipient), on moral judgments and SNAP policy support.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 (grocery choice: healthful, unhealthful) x 2 (shopper type: SNAP recipient; poor, non-recipient) x 2 (race: white, black) between-subjects design.

q9.value: We will use simple random sampling, where each participant is randomly assigned to one of the six treatment groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific.co, an online participant recruitment and survey administration platform. Participants will be paid a rate of $0.15/minute for agreeing to participate. The study will take approximately 10-15 minutes. Participants must be 18 years old and have read and understood the informed consent.

q13.value: We will collect a sample size of 1100 participants, whom we will recruit on Prolific.co.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a standard power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a small effect size of .1 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We plan to manipulate the hypothetical shopper's receipt of SNAP. The two levels of this categorical variable are: SNAP-recipient and similarly poor non-SNAP-recipient.
We will manipulate the hypothetical shopper's race. The two levels of this categorical variable are: white and black.
We will manipulate the grocery choices of the hypothetical shopper. The two levels of this categorical variable are: healthful and unhealthful groceries.

The first outcome variable will be the perceived immorality of the hypothetical grocery shopper. We will measure this by using a moral overtones of food scale adapted from Stein and Nemeroff (1995). The adapted scale is a 12-item, 8-point bipolar scale; higher composite scores from this scale mean higher immorality.
The second outcome variable will be support of SNAP policy. This will be measured by asking participants two questions: 1. What do you think about this program (SNAP)? and 2. How do you feel about your tax dollars going toward this program? (both on a scale of 1-6, 1 being 'extremely dislike,' 6 being 'extremely like'). Higher composite scores from these two measures will mean greater SNAP support.

We will take the mean of the morality scale to create a single measure of "perceived immorality." We will create a "SNAP support" summary index by taking an equally weighted mean of z-scores of its component questions.

We will use a 2 x 2 x 2 fixed effects ANOVA with all factors between subjects to analyze our results. The manipulated independent variables are shopper type (SNAP recipient, non-recipient), race (white, black), and grocery choice (healthful, unhealthful) and the measured dependent variables are perceived immorality of the shopper and SNAP policy support. We will test for a three-way interaction effect, two-way interaction effects, and main effects of the factors. If there is no significant moderating effect of race, we will collapse responses across race for increased power to conduct a 2 (shopper type: SNAP recipient, non-recipient) x 2 (grocery choice: healthful, unhealthful) fixed effects, between-subjects ANOVA. We will also conduct a mediation model to test for indirect effects of immorality on SNAP support and vice versa. We will use attention and manipulation checks to ensure participants have read our scenario carefully and to assess how participants perceived our independent variables.

q20.value: Categorical predictors will be dummy coded (race reference = white, SNAP receipt reference = non-recipient, grocery choice reference = healthful). We do not expect to transform data from the measured variables unless the data do not fit a normal distribution.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA suggests the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: I will exclude participants who answer all attention checks incorrectly. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete the survey, the subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits and individual differences may be associated with immorality judgments and support of SNAP. We will look for relationships between demographic variables (e.g., age, gender, political affiliation, income) and the primary outcome measures, and interactions between demographic variables and manipulated variables on outcome measures. We will also look at relationships between manipulation check responses and primary outcome measures.

q25.value: We have conducted 3 prior studies within this project. The first was a two-cell (grocery choice: healthful, unhealthful) between-subjects design. The second was a 2 (grocery choice: healthful, unhealthful) x 2 (race: white, black) between-subjects design. The third was a three-cell (shopper: not-poor; poor, non-recipient; SNAP recipient) between-subjects design. All prior studies were conducted on the Cloud Research Platform using MTurk participants. Lessons learned and outcome effect sizes from these prior studies helped inform this study's design and sample size.

attributes.title: Assessing the measurement characteristics of prominent socio-emotional skills among underrepresented Indian girls

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 500 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 250 participants in the prime condition and 250 participants in the control condition.

analyses.value:
We will conduct 5 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each dependent measure—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on these measures of conservatism. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct 3 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each disgust score—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on disgust. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

We will conduct 3 separate mediation models using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether effects of the manipulation on each of these three outcomes—disapproval of gay marriage, disapproval of casual sex, and disapproval of anal sex—is mediated by disgust toward each act.

For more parsimonious data analysis, we will compute 2 new variables to represent “disgust” and “domain-specific conservatism.” Our disgust variable will be the mean of participants’ disgust scores for gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Our domain-specific conservatism will be the mean of participants’ disapproval scores for gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Then, for moderation analyses, we will conduct 4 separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of the manipulation on each of these outcomes—ideal political ideology, moral foundations purity, disgust, and domain-specific conservatism—differs by level of pandemic concern. For ideal political ideology, we will regress ideal political ideology on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For purity, we will regress purity on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For disgust, we will regress disgust on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For domain-specific conservatism, we will regress domain-specific conservatism on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are unfamiliar with the coronavirus pandemic, fail an attention check in the survey, or enter that they are an unpermitted (<18 years) age. Participants who report being LGBTQ+ will be excluded from analyses related to gay marriage disgust and disapproval.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include ideal political ideology, moral foundations purity, disapproval of gay marriage, disapproval of casual sex, and disapproval of anal sex.

Ideal political ideology will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), what type of political views do you think are ideal?”

Concern for moral foundations purity will be assessed by the 3-item purity subscale of the Moral Foundations Questionnaire, which measures the extent to which considerations of purity are relevant to participants’ moral judgments. An example item is “whether or not someone did something disgusting.” Responses will range from 1 (not at all relevant) to 6 (extremely relevant).

Disapproval of gay marriage will be assessed by the following 6 items: “Gay marriage threatens the meaning of the traditional family,” “Gay marriage weakens the morals of society,” “I morally disapprove of gay marriage,” “Gay marriage should be illegal,” “Marriage should only occur between a man and a woman,” and “Gay marriage is simply wrong.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Disapproval of casual sex will be assessed by the following 5 items: “Casual sex weakens the morals of society,” “I morally disapprove of casual sex,” “Casual sex threatens the meaning of proper relationships,” “Sex should only occur between partners who are exclusively committed to each other long-term,” and  “Casual sex is simply wrong.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Disapproval of anal sex will be assessed by the following 5 items: “I morally disapprove of anal sex,” “Anal sex weakens the morals of society,” “Anal sex threatens the meaning of proper sexual relationships,” “Anal sex is simply wrong,” and  “Anal sex should be discouraged.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Mediator variables include disgust toward each of the 3 sex-related acts listed above: gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Disgust toward each act will be assessed by a 3-item scale. The disgust scale for each behavior will follow the same format. The 3 items for disgust toward gay marriage are, “Gay marriage is disgusting,” “The thought of gay people getting married makes me feel repulsed,” and “Gay marriage is gross.” The 3 items for disgust toward casual sex are, “Casual sex is disgusting,” “The thought of having casual sex makes me feel repulsed,” and “Casual sex is gross.” The 3 items for disgust toward anal sex are, “Anal sex is disgusting,” “The thought of having anal sex makes me feel repulsed,” and “Anal sex is gross.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The manipulation in this study is whether participants reflect on the coronavirus pandemic before or after they complete the dependent measures. Participants will reflect on the pandemic in the following manner. First, participants be asked, “Have you heard about the current coronavirus pandemic?” to which responses include “yes” and “no.” Second, participants will be asked, “Please take a moment to reflect on the coronavirus pandemic and how you feel about it...” Third, participants will be asked, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “moderately concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.”

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question within the manipulation, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses from “not at all” to “extremely concerned” scored respectively from 1 to 5.

conditions.value: There are two conditions in this survey: a “coronavirus prime” condition and a “no prime” control condition. Participants will be randomly assigned to one condition. Participants in the prime condition will complete the manipulation task before completing any dependent measures, whereas participants in the control condition will complete the dependent measures before the manipulation task.

hypothesis.value: We will test whether reflecting on the coronavirus makes people more conservative. We hypothesize that upon reflecting on the pandemic, participants will report that they view a more conservative political ideology as ideal, rely more on the moral foundation purity, disapprove more strongly of gay marriage, disapprove more strongly of casual sex, and disapprove more strongly of anal sex. We hypothesize that effects for disapproval of gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex will be mediated by disgust toward each act, with disgust being higher upon reflecting on the pandemic. We hypothesize that all of these effects will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Coronavirus Conservatism Experiment
registration_responses.sample: We will recruit 500 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 250 participants in the prime condition and 250 participants in the control condition.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will conduct 5 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each dependent measure—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on these measures of conservatism. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct 3 separate independent samples t-tests—one for each disgust score—to test whether the manipulation had significant effects on disgust. We will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

We will conduct 3 separate mediation models using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether effects of the manipulation on each of these three outcomes—disapproval of gay marriage, disapproval of casual sex, and disapproval of anal sex—is mediated by disgust toward each act.

For more parsimonious data analysis, we will compute 2 new variables to represent “disgust” and “domain-specific conservatism.” Our disgust variable will be the mean of participants’ disgust scores for gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Our domain-specific conservatism will be the mean of participants’ disapproval scores for gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Then, for moderation analyses, we will conduct 4 separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of the manipulation on each of these outcomes—ideal political ideology, moral foundations purity, disgust, and domain-specific conservatism—differs by level of pandemic concern. For ideal political ideology, we will regress ideal political ideology on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For purity, we will regress purity on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For disgust, we will regress disgust on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. For domain-specific conservatism, we will regress domain-specific conservatism on manipulation condition, pandemic concern, and the interaction term for condition and concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

Participants who report being LGBTQ+ will be excluded from analyses related to gay marriage disgust and disapproval.

Dependent variables include ideal political ideology, moral foundations purity, disapproval of gay marriage, disapproval of casual sex, and disapproval of anal sex.

Ideal political ideology will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), what type of political views do you think are ideal?”

Concern for moral foundations purity will be assessed by the 3-item purity subscale of the Moral Foundations Questionnaire, which measures the extent to which considerations of purity are relevant to participants’ moral judgments. An example item is “whether or not someone did something disgusting.” Responses will range from 1 (not at all relevant) to 6 (extremely relevant).

Disapproval of gay marriage will be assessed by the following 6 items: “Gay marriage threatens the meaning of the traditional family,” “Gay marriage weakens the morals of society,” “I morally disapprove of gay marriage,” “Gay marriage should be illegal,” “Marriage should only occur between a man and a woman,” and “Gay marriage is simply wrong.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Disapproval of casual sex will be assessed by the following 5 items: “Casual sex weakens the morals of society,” “I morally disapprove of casual sex,” “Casual sex threatens the meaning of proper relationships,” “Sex should only occur between partners who are exclusively committed to each other long-term,” and  “Casual sex is simply wrong.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Disapproval of anal sex will be assessed by the following 5 items: “I morally disapprove of anal sex,” “Anal sex weakens the morals of society,” “Anal sex threatens the meaning of proper sexual relationships,” “Anal sex is simply wrong,” and  “Anal sex should be discouraged.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Mediator variables include disgust toward each of the 3 sex-related acts listed above: gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex. Disgust toward each act will be assessed by a 3-item scale. The disgust scale for each behavior will follow the same format. The 3 items for disgust toward gay marriage are, “Gay marriage is disgusting,” “The thought of gay people getting married makes me feel repulsed,” and “Gay marriage is gross.” The 3 items for disgust toward casual sex are, “Casual sex is disgusting,” “The thought of having casual sex makes me feel repulsed,” and “Casual sex is gross.” The 3 items for disgust toward anal sex are, “Anal sex is disgusting,” “The thought of having anal sex makes me feel repulsed,” and “Anal sex is gross.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The manipulation in this study is whether participants reflect on the coronavirus pandemic before or after they complete the dependent measures. Participants will reflect on the pandemic in the following manner. First, participants be asked, “Have you heard about the current coronavirus pandemic?” to which responses include “yes” and “no.” Second, participants will be asked, “Please take a moment to reflect on the coronavirus pandemic and how you feel about it...” Third, participants will be asked, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “moderately concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.”

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question within the manipulation, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses from “not at all” to “extremely concerned” scored respectively from 1 to 5.
registration_responses.conditions: There are two conditions in this survey: a “coronavirus prime” condition and a “no prime” control condition. Participants will be randomly assigned to one condition. Participants in the prime condition will complete the manipulation task before completing any dependent measures, whereas participants in the control condition will complete the dependent measures before the manipulation task.
registration_responses.hypothesis: We will test whether reflecting on the coronavirus makes people more conservative. We hypothesize that upon reflecting on the pandemic, participants will report that they view a more conservative political ideology as ideal, rely more on the moral foundation purity, disapprove more strongly of gay marriage, disapprove more strongly of casual sex, and disapprove more strongly of anal sex. We hypothesize that effects for disapproval of gay marriage, casual sex, and anal sex will be mediated by disgust toward each act, with disgust being higher upon reflecting on the pandemic. We hypothesize that all of these effects will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will advertise this “time 2” survey on MTurk to all of the 1,000 workers who participated in the “time 1” survey. Our sample size will be the number of workers who complete this “time 2” survey within a 2-week period.

analyses.value: We will conduct a paired t-test, comparing participants’ willingness to try cultured meat at time 2 versus time 1. To test whether this effect is moderated by participants’ levels of concern with the coronavirus pandemic, we will conduct a mixed ANOVA, with the within-subjects factor being time (time 1 vs. time 2) and the between-subjects factor being level of pandemic concern (low vs. high). If an interaction effect between time and concern is significant, then we will follow up by conducting simple main effects of time within each level of concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they report that they are vegetarian, fail an attention check in this “time 2” survey, or if they failed an attention check in the “time 1” survey.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is willingness to try cultured meat. Prior to indicating their willingness to try cultured meat, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about “in vitro meat.” In vitro meat is an animal flesh product that has never been part of a living animal, but is instead grown in a laboratory using muscle stem cells. In vitro meat is also referred to as cultured meat, cell-based meat, or synthetic meat. In August 2013, scientists unveiled (and tasted) the world's first in vitro grown hamburger patty. Currently, in vitro meat is not commercially available, though research is being conducted to introduce it as a potential new meat production technique for the future.” Willingness to try cultured meat will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to try in vitro meat?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.” Participants who indicate that they are either “not at all” or “somewhat concerned” will be categorized as low in concern, whereas participants who indicate that they are either “very concerned” or “extremely concerned” will be categorized as high in concern.

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.

hypothesis.value: The present study will be a “time 2” assessment for a larger longitudinal study. Thus, all participants will have participated in the “time 1” study, in which we assessed how willing they were to try cultured meat. We will test whether people’s attitudes toward this eating behavior changed with the development of the coronavirus pandemic. We hypothesize that, compared to before the pandemic (time 1), after the start of the pandemic (time 2), people will be less willing to try cultured meat. We hypothesize that this effect will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Coronavirus Eating Longitudinal Time 2
registration_responses.sample: We will advertise this “time 2” survey on MTurk to all of the 1,000 workers who participated in the “time 1” survey. Our sample size will be the number of workers who complete this “time 2” survey within a 2-week period.
registration_responses.analyses: We will conduct a paired t-test, comparing participants’ willingness to try cultured meat at time 2 versus time 1. To test whether this effect is moderated by participants’ levels of concern with the coronavirus pandemic, we will conduct a mixed ANOVA, with the within-subjects factor being time (time 1 vs. time 2) and the between-subjects factor being level of pandemic concern (low vs. high). If an interaction effect between time and concern is significant, then we will follow up by conducting simple main effects of time within each level of concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they report that they are vegetarian, fail an attention check in this “time 2” survey, or if they failed an attention check in the “time 1” survey.
registration_responses.dependent:
The dependent variable is willingness to try cultured meat. Prior to indicating their willingness to try cultured meat, participants will read the following prompt: “We are curious to hear what you think about “in vitro meat.” In vitro meat is an animal flesh product that has never been part of a living animal, but is instead grown in a laboratory using muscle stem cells. In vitro meat is also referred to as cultured meat, cell-based meat, or synthetic meat. In August 2013, scientists unveiled (and tasted) the world's first in vitro grown hamburger patty. Currently, in vitro meat is not commercially available, though research is being conducted to introduce it as a potential new meat production technique for the future.” Willingness to try cultured meat will then be assessed by the question, “Would you be willing to try in vitro meat?” with responses (and how they will be scored in parentheses; not shown to participants) including no, definitely not (1); no, probably not (2); unsure (3); yes, maybe (4); and yes, definitely (5).

A moderator variable will be the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic. This will be assessed by the question, “How concerned are you about the health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic?” with responses including “not at all,” “somewhat concerned,” “very concerned,” and “extremely concerned.” Participants who indicate that they are either “not at all” or “somewhat concerned” will be categorized as low in concern, whereas participants who indicate that they are either “very concerned” or “extremely concerned” will be categorized as high in concern.
registration_responses.conditions: There are no conditions in this survey; all participants will complete the same survey.
registration_responses.hypothesis: The present study will be a “time 2” assessment for a larger longitudinal study. Thus, all participants will have participated in the “time 1” study, in which we assessed how willing they were to try cultured meat. We will test whether people’s attitudes toward this eating behavior changed with the development of the coronavirus pandemic. We hypothesize that, compared to before the pandemic (time 1), after the start of the pandemic (time 2), people will be less willing to try cultured meat. We hypothesize that this effect will be moderated by the extent to which participants are concerned about the coronavirus pandemic, being larger for participants who are high in concern than for participants who are low in concern.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Structure and Principles: indirect effects with control for social and economic conservatism.

sample.value: 400 participants will be recruited on Amazon's mechanical turk pre-exclusion.

analyses.value:
First, we will compute a generalized linear mixed-effects model (LMEM) with PNS as a fixed-effect, and with beliefs about whether there are exceptions to the moral principles as the outcome variable (0 = at least one exception, 1 = no exceptions). Principle and subject will be crossed random effects (random intercepts only). We may also average ratings across principles to compute a correlation between PNS and the proportion of principles that are exceptionless. 

Second, we will compute a LMEM with PNS as a fixed-effect, and with punishment judgments as the outcome variable. Principle and subject will be crossed random effects (random intercepts only). We may also average ratings across principles to compute a correlation between PNS and punishment judgments. 

Third, we hypothesized that the personal need for structure would be indirectly related to punitive judgments toward moral principle violators via beliefs about whether the moral principles admit of exceptions. To test this indirect relationship, we will use the PROCESS macro from Hayes (2012) with 5,000 bootstrap resamples. This requires averaging across principles to obtain one "exceptions" rating and one "punishment" rating per subject.

For each of these models, we will then add social and economic conservatism measures to the models to statistically control for these variables.

outliers.value: The study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value:
To address the primary hypothesis, participants will be presented with 12 moral principles, and for each one they will report how much a person who violates the principle should be punished on a 6-pt scale (1 = not at all, 6 = very much).

To address the other hypothesis, participants will make a binary choice about whether or not each of the 12 principles admit of exceptions.

hypothesis.value: The primary hypothesis is that personal need for structure (PNS) will be indirectly related to punitive judgments toward moral principle violators via beliefs about whether the moral principles admit of exceptions. In the process of addressing this primary goal, we also address this hypothesis: that individuals higher in PNS are more likely to report that moral principles are exceptionless. Moreover, we also address this hypothesis: that individuals higher in PNS will tend to make stronger punitive judgments toward moral principle violators. Finally, we make sure that all of these effects hold after statistically controlling for social and economic conservatism.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

Third, we hypothesized that the personal need for structure would be indirectly related to punitive judgments toward moral principle violators via beliefs about whether the moral principles admit of exceptions. For each of these models, we will then add social and economic conservatism measures to the models to statistically control for these variables.

Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

To address the other hypothesis, participants will make a binary choice about whether or not each of the 12 principles admit of exceptions.
registration_responses.hypothesis: The primary hypothesis is that personal need for structure (PNS) will be indirectly related to punitive judgments toward moral principle violators via beliefs about whether the moral principles admit of exceptions. attributes.title: Transparency and open science standards in the policies of medical and health science journals
attributes.description: An evaluation of the policies of health and medical science journals with respect to transparency and open science standards

q1.value: Increasing adoption of open science standards in medical and health science journals: a proof-of-concept study

q2.value: Hopin Lee, Georgia C. Richards, David Nunan, Antoni Dariusz Gardener, Yi Jie Gifford Tan, Ellie Hick, Chloe Jacklin

q3.value:
In a previous study, we audited 20 leading medical and health journals for their information on transparent and open science practices using the Transparency and Openness Promotion (TOP) guidelines and the Centre for Open Science (COS) scorecard. The full methods for our previous study are available here (https://osf.io/hx5ca). Briefly, we reviewed each journal for the level of adherence to the minimum transparency research standards using the COS scorecard. This includes eight transparency standards in the TOP guidelines (https://cos.io/top/) as well as three additional items (TOP signatory, registered reports, open science badges). A total score out of 29 is determined by combining the COS score total (the combined score of each of the 8 transparency standards (scored between 0 to 24) with the scores for the three additional items - TOP signatory (0 = no, 1 = yes), registered reports (0 = no, 2 = yes) and open science badges (0 = no, 2 = yes). Separately, we also assessed each journal for their adherence to four of the standards found in the ICMJE disclosure form for conflicts of interest (COI), scoring a total out of four.

The findings of our audit were:
1. The highest scoring journals were Cell, Nature Medicine, Nature Neuroscience and Neuron, all with a COS score of 14 (out of 29). The lowest scoring journal was the Journal of the American College of Cardiology, with a COS score of 0. The median COS score was 6.5 (IQR 2-13) 
2. The COS TOP standard that consistently scored lowest across the included journals were analysis plan preregistration and replication. The COS TOP standard that consistently scored highest across the included journals was data transparency.
3. The majority (17/20) of journals stated all four ICMJE requirements for disclosure of interests, the exceptions being Cell (3 out of 4), Journal of Clinical Oncology (3 out of 4) and Neuron (3 out of 4).

Overall, there appears a disappointing lack of engagement with open and transparent research practices in the highest-ranked medical and health journals. Our findings replicate those of another study that performed a similar audit of journals specialising in pain research (Cashin et al., 2020). The natural question to ask is how do we encourage journals to improve this situation? Indeed, Cashin and colleagues called for future research assessing interventions to facilitate uptake of better transparency and open science practices. 

We, therefore, set about to investigate the possible impact of a simple intervention on positive changes of the medical and health journals we audited in our first study. We also performed a follow-up audit as part of this assessment and outline our protocol below.

Purpose: To perform a re-audit and assessment of the potential impact of informing high-ranking medical and health science journals of the findings from an audit of the information they provide related to transparent and open research practices.

Research questions
1. Does a re-audit of 20 leading medical journals demonstrate a change in their COS score for transparency and open science?
2. How does a Letter to the Editor (LTE) or similar correspondence to the journal informing on results of our audit impact on:
2.1 Acceptance of a ‘Letter to the editor’ (LTE) relaying the audit findings?
2.2 Willingness to address issues identified by the audit?
2.3 Enactment of changes to address issues highlighted by the audit findings?

q4.value: We hypothesise that informed journals will accept all letters to the editor, actively engage with communications and enact necessary changes regarding transparent and open science practices within a 4-month period.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Re-evaluation of transparency and open science information and standards for 20 medical and health science journals. We will narratively compare the findings from an audit carried out in February 2020 to a re-audit carried out in June 2020. A proof-of-concept study will be performed to assess the impact of informing a journal of our intention to carry out a re-audit of their journal after a 4-month period.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will assess as a proof-of-concept the potential impact of informing journals about our TOP audit findings. Journals will be randomised to receive one of two LTEs. Both LTEs will include the following information:
1. Information about the Take up TOP initiative;
2. A brief description of our audit methods with links to this preregistered protocol
3. A summary of our audit findings, including how their journal COS and ICMJE scores rank in comparison with those of the other audited journals

In addition to the above information, one letter (LTE-1) will include a concluding statement regarding the need for transparency and open science standards to be acknowledged and enacted by high-ranking medical/health science journals. This will be for the control group. Letter two (LTE-2) will include the same concluding statement but will also include information of our intention to conduct a re-audit of their journal after in June 2020. This will form the intervention group. 

We will compare the audit findings from February 2020 to June 2020 to evaluate the potential impact of different communication strategies on journal policy updates as well acceptance rates of LTEs.

q14.value: We will assess the highest-ranked journals in the ‘Health & Medical Sciences’ subcategory of Google Scholar as listed on Friday, 31 January 2020 (full list available online here)

question.value: We will calculate the total COS score for each journal by summing the values together (possible score ranging from 0 to 29). We will determine the total ICMJE score by summing the values together (possible score ranging from 0 to 4). We will calculate the median and interquartile range for COS scores across the 20 journals. We will determine the difference in COS scores subtracting the COS score obtained in the re-audit of June 2020 from that of the COS score obtained in the first audit in February 2020. We will determine the difference in ICMJE scores by subtracting the ICMJE score obtained in the re-audit of June 2020 from that of the ICMJE score obtained in the first audit in February 2020. Where possible, we will assess the potential impact of providing journals with information on a re-audit in addition to information about our audit findings alone. We will do this by comparing change/re-audit scores in those journals randomly assigned to LTE-2 (intervention) with those randomly assigned to LTE-1. We will determine the acceptance rate for LTEs by totalling the number of journals who accept the letter and divide this by the total number of journals included in this analysis (n=20). We will compare the effect of being randomised to receiving different information on the uptake of LTEs by comparing acceptance to publish LTEs in those journals receiving LTE-1 compared with those receiving LTE-2.

q25.value:
GCR is funded by the NIHR SPCR, the Naji Foundation and the Rotary Foundation to study for a Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Oxford. GCR is an Ambassador for the Centre for Open Science and is the Editorial Registrar for BMJ Evidence Based Medicine. HL is funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council (grant
no. APP1126767); National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Collaboration for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care Oxford at Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust; received
project funding from the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences, a program of the Center for Effective Global Action (CEGA), with support from the Laura and John Arnold
Foundation; and is a Catalyst for the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences. DN is a member of the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) steering committee to support the new Physical Activity and Lifestyle clinical priority. He has received funding for research from the NHS National Institute for Health Research School for Primary Care Research (NIHR SPCR) and the RCGP for independent research projects related to physical activity and dietary interventions. The views expressed are those of the author and not necessarily those of the NHS, the NIHR, the RCGP or the Department of Health.

attributes.title: What is the value of privacy?

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: What value do people place on their close friend’s privacy?

other.value: We explore whether concern for privacy, risk, or trust moderate the effect of WTA/WTP. Do people who are more concerned with privacy report a higher WTA/WTP?

sample.value: Based on apriori power analysis for an effect size f = 0.2, alpha = 0.05, and 80% power, we require a sample size of 246. However, based on a previous study that uses a similar approach, we will collect a study with at least 350 participants divided equally across the three conditions.

analyses.value:
For each domain separately, we do the following analyses:
1.	To test hypothesis 1, we run a one-way ANOVA between the conditions (privacy, no privacy, and choice) comparing the amount of money willing to pay or accept in each condition. In this model, for the choice condition, we will separately code WTA for those who chose privacy and those who did not. Hence, there will be four groups compared here: privacy, no privacy, those who chose privacy, and those who did not choose privacy.
2.	To test hypothesis 2, we run a Pearson chi-square test to compare number of people who choose the privacy option to the number of people who chose the other option. Here, we test whether the observed distribution of choosing the two options differs significantly from a distribution where each option is equally likely.
3.	To test hypothesis 3, we run an independent samples t-test comparing the WTA of those who initially choose the privacy option to those who do not choose the privacy option.
We also run analyses including all the domains. We run a multilevel model with participants nested within domains with WTA/WTP as the dependent variable and condition as a fixed effect. We include participant and domain as random effects in the model.

outliers.value: Analyses will include all participants with available data i.e., a participant will be excluded if there is a missing value for a particular variable that is being used in the model but will be included in a different model if the variable used there has no missing value.

dependent.value:
We have two main dependent measures: WTA (for conditions 1 and 3) and WTP (for condition 2).
Participants see a slider ranging from 0 – 50 euros where they indicate how much they are willing to accept or pay depending on the condition. The following are the full questions for each condition.

1.	WTA
“You will now be asked to indicate how much money (in euros) you would be willing to accept to switch to the discounted version. You should select the minimum price that you would like to receive for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the discounted one for your close friend.
Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the discounted version when you pay X€ or more. Hence, you would be willing to accept a minimum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to accept lower than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the premium version.  

2.	WTP
“You will now be asked to indicate how much money (in euros) you would be willing to pay to switch to the premium version. 
You should select the maximum price that you would like to pay for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the premium one for your close friend.

Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the premium version when you pay X€ or less. Hence, you would be willing to pay a maximum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to pay higher than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the discounted version.”

3.	Choice condition (WTA)
“You will now be asked to indicate for which price you would be willing to switch to the other version. 
You should select the minimum price that you would like to receive for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the other one for your close friend.

Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the other version when you pay X€ or more. Hence, you would be willing to accept a minimum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to accept lower than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the current version you chose.”

Other measured variables:
Additionally, we also include a measure of privacy concerns, measures of risk and trust within domains, and demographic information. We also measure how much people think the service/app costs (baseline).

conditions.value:
For each domain, we use a between-subjects design where we have three conditions:
1.	Premium version where a close friend’s privacy is endowed and participants indicate how much money they would accept to give up their close friend’s privacy (privacy condition)
2.	Discounted version where a close friend’s privacy is violated and participants indicate how much money they would be willing to pay to gain their close friend’s privacy (no privacy condition)
3.	Participants choose between premium and discounted versions for their close friend and then have to indicate how much money would they be willing to accept to switch the other version. (choice condition)

hypothesis.value:
Using five domains (apps/services) where personal data could be used and privacy could be violated (social media service, dating apps, store membership cards, transport cards, and shopping gift cards), we investigate the following questions:
1.	Do people value their close friend’s privacy more when their friend is already endowed with privacy as compared to when he/she not endowed with it?
2.	Do people value their close friend’s privacy more when their friend is endowed with privacy as compared to when they are given a choice between an option that includes privacy and an option that violates privacy?
3.	Is this valuation similar or different across domains?

We test the following hypotheses:
1.	We predict that people are more likely to choose the option that protects their close friend’s privacy when given a free choice to choose between a version that protects privacy vs a version that violates privacy. 
2.	We also predict that those who initially choose the option with privacy for their close friend will have a higher WTA compared to those who initially do not choose the option with privacy.
3.	We predict that the amount of money people require or accept (willingness to accept – WTA) to give up their close friend’s privacy is higher than the amount of money they are willing to pay (willingness to pay – WTP) to get back their close friend’s privacy.
4.	We also predict that the WTA to give up their close friend’s privacy when privacy is endowed is higher than when they have the choice to pick the option that protects privacy.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: What value do people place on their close friend’s privacy?
registration_responses.other: We explore whether concern for privacy, risk, or trust moderate the effect of WTA/WTP. Do people who are more concerned with privacy report a higher WTA/WTP?
registration_responses.sample: Based on apriori power analysis for an effect size f = 0.2, alpha = 0.05, and 80% power, we require a sample size of 246. However, based on a previous study that uses a similar approach, we will collect a study with at least 350 participants divided equally across the three conditions.

For each domain separately, we do the following analyses:
1.	To test hypothesis 1, we run a one-way ANOVA between the conditions (privacy, no privacy, and choice) comparing the amount of money willing to pay or accept in each condition. In this model, for the choice condition, we will separately code WTA for those who chose privacy and those who did not. Hence, there will be four groups compared here: privacy, no privacy, those who chose privacy, and those who did not choose privacy.
2.	To test hypothesis 2, we run a Pearson chi-square test to compare number of people who choose the privacy option to the number of people who chose the other option. Here, we test whether the observed distribution of choosing the two options differs significantly from a distribution where each option is equally likely.
3.	To test hypothesis 3, we run an independent samples t-test comparing the WTA of those who initially choose the privacy option to those who do not choose the privacy option.
We also run analyses including all the domains. We run a multilevel model with participants nested within domains with WTA/WTP as the dependent variable and condition as a fixed effect. We include participant and domain as random effects in the model.
registration_responses.outliers: Analyses will include all participants with available data i.e., a participant will be excluded if there is a missing value for a particular variable that is being used in the model but will be included in a different model if the variable used there has no missing value.
registration_responses.dependent:
We have two main dependent measures: WTA (for conditions 1 and 3) and WTP (for condition 2).
Participants see a slider ranging from 0 – 50 euros where they indicate how much they are willing to accept or pay depending on the condition. The following are the full questions for each condition.

1.	WTA
“You will now be asked to indicate how much money (in euros) you would be willing to accept to switch to the discounted version. You should select the minimum price that you would like to receive for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the discounted one for your close friend.
Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the discounted version when you pay X€ or more. Hence, you would be willing to accept a minimum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to accept lower than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the premium version.  

2.	WTP
“You will now be asked to indicate how much money (in euros) you would be willing to pay to switch to the premium version. 
You should select the maximum price that you would like to pay for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the premium one for your close friend.

Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the premium version when you pay X€ or less. Hence, you would be willing to pay a maximum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to pay higher than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the discounted version.”

3.	Choice condition (WTA)
“You will now be asked to indicate for which price you would be willing to switch to the other version. 
You should select the minimum price that you would like to receive for which you would be willing to give up the current version and switch to the other one for your close friend.

Example: If you choose X€, then this means you are willing to switch to the other version when you pay X€ or more. Hence, you would be willing to accept a minimum of X€ to switch. But you would not be willing to accept lower than X€ to switch. 
If you are not willing to switch at all, choose 0€. This means your friend keeps the current version you chose.”

Other measured variables:
Additionally, we also include a measure of privacy concerns, measures of risk and trust within domains, and demographic information. We also measure how much people think the service/app costs (baseline).
registration_responses.conditions:
For each domain, we use a between-subjects design where we have three conditions:
1.	Premium version where a close friend’s privacy is endowed and participants indicate how much money they would accept to give up their close friend’s privacy (privacy condition)
2.	Discounted version where a close friend’s privacy is violated and participants indicate how much money they would be willing to pay to gain their close friend’s privacy (no privacy condition)
3.	Participants choose between premium and discounted versions for their close friend and then have to indicate how much money would they be willing to accept to switch the other version. (choice condition)
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Using five domains (apps/services) where personal data could be used and privacy could be violated (social media service, dating apps, store membership cards, transport cards, and shopping gift cards), we investigate the following questions:
1.	Do people value their close friend’s privacy more when their friend is already endowed with privacy as compared to when he/she not endowed with it?
2.	Do people value their close friend’s privacy more when their friend is endowed with privacy as compared to when they are given a choice between an option that includes privacy and an option that violates privacy?
3.	Is this valuation similar or different across domains?

We test the following hypotheses:
1.	We predict that people are more likely to choose the option that protects their close friend’s privacy when given a free choice to choose between a version that protects privacy vs a version that violates privacy. 
2.	We also predict that those who initially choose the option with privacy for their close friend will have a higher WTA compared to those who initially do not choose the option with privacy.
3.	We predict that the amount of money people require or accept (willingness to accept – WTA) to give up their close friend’s privacy is higher than the amount of money they are willing to pay (willingness to pay – WTP) to get back their close friend’s privacy.
4.	We also predict that the WTA to give up their close friend’s privacy when privacy is endowed is higher than when they have the choice to pick the option that protects privacy.
